isis.stitle: DIAMONDLIFE™ (BOSCH PIN SLIDE) DISC BRAKES For Vehicles Built Before June 3, 2002 - REMOVE - DISC BRAKE PADS

svcprocinfo.para: There are three types of lining materials available for the hydraulic pin slide brake system. HX-7A1-EE brake pads and softer lining brake pads identified by lining code 7610 with smooth backing plates for heavy duty braking applications and HX-402-EE brake pads for light duty braking applications.

item.para:
The HX-7A1-EE lining material of inboard disc brake pad (Item 1, Figure 3)
and outboard disc brake pad (Item 2, Figure 3)
are chamfered and are marked with an "ARROW" and the word "FORWARD" for proper installation. Brake pads are NOT interchangeable from inboard to outboard side on the same wheel.

The optional HX-402-EE lining material of inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Item 3, Figure 3)
are NOT chamfered and ARE interchangeable from inboard to outboard side on the same wheel.

The optional SOFTER lining material of inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Item 3, Figure 3)
are NOT chamfered and ARE interchangeable from inboard to outboard side on the same wheel.

svcprocinfo.para: As lining wears on disc brake pads, brake fluid level in the reservoir will lower. Before servicing the calipers, inspect the fluid level. If the fluid level is at or near proper fluid level, remove some brake fluid from the reservoir, using a siphon or syringe. When the pistons are pushed back into the caliper piston bores the fluid will be pushed back to the reservoir and may overflow if not removed. Discard the used fluid removed from the master cylinder.

If inspection reveals that caliper piston boots are worn or damaged, replace them. Refer to CALIPER, Remove
, CALIPER, Disassemble
, CALIPER, Clean and Inspect
, CALIPER, Assemble
and CALIPER, Install
to remove, disassemble, clean and inspect, assemble and install to repair or replace caliper.

During service procedure, keep grease and other foreign material from caliper assembly, disc brake pads, brake rotor and external surfaces of hub. Handle parts carefully to avoid damage to caliper, rotor, disc brake pads and brake lines.
The following steps refer to only one wheel. The same procedure will need to be performed at each wheel.

svcsubproc.title: Remove

step1.para: Position vehicle on suitable floor stands and remove wheel (tire and rim). Refer to GROUP 17 - WHEELS in the Master Service Manual for proper wheel (tire and rim) removal.

warning.para: A jack must never be used alone to support a vehicle while under-chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with suitable floor stands.

step1.para: Inspect master cylinder fluid level and remove fluid if necessary as described above.
Insert a screwdriver in one of the rotor cooling fin slots and pry the caliper outboard pushing the caliper pistons into the piston bores. This will allow removal of caliper (Figure 13).

figure.caption: Figure 13. Push Caliper Outboard Pushing Pistons into Piston Bores

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 14 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: On front axles only, remove hex nut and lock washer (Item 1) and lift brake line retaining clip (Item 2) off threaded stud (Item 3) on the steering knuckle hose support bracket (Item 4). This will allow the brake line hose to hang free.

figure.caption: Figure 14. Removing Brake Line Retaining Clip from Front Axle Hose Support Bracket

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 15 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: On rear axles only, if vehicle is equipped with ABS brake system and/or air suspension system, note that the brake line hose (Item 1) is attached to ABS sensor cable (Item 2) with tywrap straps (Item 3) from retaining clip (Item 4) on axle (Item 5) to disc brake assembly (Item 6). Remove hex head bolt (Item 7) from retaining clip (Item 4). Remove hex head bolt (Item 8) and brake line retaining clip (Item 9) from caliper (Item 10). This will allow the brake line hose to hang free while rotating the caliper down to replace disc brake pads.

important.para: If it becomes necessary to cut any of the tywrap straps (Item 3) to allow caliper to rotate all the way down during disc brake pad replacement, note the location of the tywrap strap before cutting it off, so it can be replaced in the proper place after service is completed.

figure.caption: Figure 15. Removing Brake Line Retaining Clips from Rear Axle and Caliper

warning.para: Never remove lower (bottom) hex mounting bolt securing caliper to anchor plate during disc brake pad service procedure. The caliper will not rotate over top center and will fall, which may cause personal injury (Figure 16).

figure.caption: Figure 16. DO NOT Raise Caliper as Shown

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 17 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Remove upper (top) hex mounting bolt (Item 1) securing the caliper (Item 2) to the anchor plate (Item 3), driver side front brake shown.

important.para: When servicing disc brake pads only, loosen and remove the upper (top) caliper hex mounting bolt (Item 1) only. Do not loosen lower (bottom) hex mounting bolt (Item 4). For proper tightening and torquing sequence refer to install section for disc brake pads.

figure.caption: Figure 17. Remove Upper Hex Mounting Bolt to Lower Caliper to Replace Disc Brake Pads

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 18 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Carefully rotate the caliper (Item 1) open about the lower (bottom) hex mounting bolt and guide pin (Items 2 and 3).
Do not allow the brake line hose (Item 4) to become pinched or kinked, driver side front brake shown.

note.para:
Use care to avoid damaging or dislodging the upper (top) or lower (bottom) guide pin boots (Items 5 and 7). Do not pull on guide pins (Items 3 and 6), this may dislodge guide pin boot from guide pin or anchor plate grooves. If boot is dislodged, refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble to repair or replace guide pin boots.

figure.caption: Figure 18. Rotate Caliper Open About Lower Hex Mounting Bolt and Guide Pin

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 19 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Remove inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2) from anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 3), driver side front and rear brake shown.

Remove anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 3) from anchor plate pad abutment, driver side front and rear brake shown. New anchor plate pad abutment slippers are supplied with new disc brake pad sets.

figure.caption: Figure 19. Remove Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads

caution.para:
Use care to avoid damaging or dislodging the guide pin boots (Item 4, Figure 19)
while cleaning machined surfaces of caliper, guide pin mounting face and anchor plate with hand held wire brush. If boot is damaged or dislodged, refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble to repair or replace guide pin boots. Do not get solvent on guide pin boots, damage to boots will occur.

step1.para:
Check machined surfaces of caliper, guide pin mounting face and anchor plate. If any rust or corrosion is present, use a hand held wire brush to clean these surfaces. It is important to clean those areas of the caliper, guide pins and anchor plate that are in contact with the brake pads or each other. If leading or trailing guide pins have rust or corrosion and can not be cleaned, it is recommended that the guide pins and hex mounting bolts be replaced. Refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble to replace guide pins.

Visually inspect caliper for leakage, damage or defects to piston boots or pistons. If leakage, damage or defects are found, repair or replace as required. Refer to CALIPER, Remove
, CALIPER, Disassemble
, CALIPER, Clean and Inspect
, CALIPER, Assemble
and CALIPER, Install
to remove, disassemble, clean and inspect, assemble and install to repair or replace caliper.

Position a metal plate over both caliper pistons, then use a "C" clamp to push both pistons into the caliper (Figure 20). Pushing the caliper pistons into the caliper will provide clearance for new disc brake pads when caliper is rotated back into position.

figure.caption: Figure 20. Push Both Pistons Into Caliper

note.para:
Several changes have been incorporated within the anchor plate assembly and caliper mounting bolts on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. It is important to recognize that these changes are not found on disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, unless a complete rebuild of the anchor plate assembly was performed on the vehicle. The components that have changed are the leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
and (Figure 68)
and caliper mounting bolts (Figure 71) .

step1.para:
Visually inspect anchor plate for damage or defects to mating surfaces at anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 3, Figure 19)
and upper guide pin head (Item 5, Figure 19) . Check that the upper guide pin is free to slide and rotate, making sure the upper guide pin head, upper hex mounting bolt and mating caliper surfaces are clean and free of grease or foreign substances. Also check that lower guide pin is free to slide and rotate before moving to next step. If guide pins are not free to rotate or slide or if other damage or defects are found, repair or replace as required.

If it is necessary to replace the guide pins, it is recommended that the old guide pins (Figure 67)
be replaced with the new guide pins (Figure 68) . When the guide pins are changed, it will be necessary to replace the old hex mounting bolts with the new hex flanged mounting bolts (Figure 71) . Refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble to repair or replace guide pins.

Visually inspect rotor for scoring, warping, cracks, bluing, heat spots or other damage or defects. If any damage or defects are found, repair or replace as required. Refer to ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY, Remove
and ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY, Install
.
